questions.text: A 66-year-old female comes to the OPD because of fatigue and oliguria for the past month, as well as hematuria for the past 2 days. After some lab investigations and a renal biopsy, she was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease. Which of the following would be the most likely in the patient's lab findings?

options.label: B
options.text: High level of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and high level of creatinine.

options.label: C
options.text: A mean corpuscular value (MCV) of more than 100 fL.

questions.correct_answer: B. High level of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and high level of creatinine.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High level of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and high level of creatinine. Chronic kidney disease refers to a reduction in renal function regardless of etiology and degree of dysfunction. As nephrons are damaged, renal function and GFR decreases and biomarkers such as creatinine are used to identify the extent of disease. Levels of BUN and creatinine show dramatic changes only after total GFR decreases to 50 percent. Initially, nephrons show adaptability.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - Inulin clearance decreases with decreases in GFR Option: C. - There is normocytic normochromic anemia due to a decrease in erythropoietin. Option: D. - GFR will decrease

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a history of sore throat 10 days ago, presented to the clinic with complaints of cola-colored urine and edema of his legs, face, and hands. Urinalysis showed red cell casts and RBCs and WBC and immunofluorescence showed this finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis It is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, history of sore throat also red cell cast, and RBC in urine. Cola-colored urine plus an IF starry sky pattern all lead to the final diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - Minimal change disease can lead to nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a group of symptoms that include protein in the urine, low blood protein levels in the blood, high cholesterol levels, high triglyceride levels, and swelling. Option: C. IgA nephropathy is an autoimmune kidney disease, meaning that the disease is due to the body's immune system attacking tissues in the kidney. Option: D. The inflammation of the kidney is due to a specific type of urinary tract infection (UTI).

Extraedge:

The renal biopsy in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis demonstrates hypercellularity of mesangial and endothelial cells ; glomerular infiltrates of polymorphonuclear leukocytes; granular subendothelial immune deposits of IgG, IgM, C3, C4, and C5–9 and subepithelial deposits (which appear as “humps”)

questions.text: A Patient, 33 years old, was found to have protein in his urine collected during the daytime .when an overnight specimen was collected there was no protein in the urine. What is this called?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Orthostatic proteinuria This is a benign condition and it is typically found in tall adolescents. Here the protein is found in the urine collected during the daytime after the patient has been ambulant. But protein is not found in the overnight specimen collected Also in this condition, there is no protein in the urine in the first-morning sample before being ambulant It occurs due to changes in renal hemodynamics on standing This is a benign condition that resolves spontaneously, with no investigation and no treatment required

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Transient proteinuria Transient proteinuria may be associated with conditions like cardiac failure, heavy exercise It disappears within hours after cessation of the exercise and with a resolution of the disease process Proteinuria after marathon running may be as heavy as 5 grams per liter of urine Option: C. Persistent proteinuria In contrast to transient and orthostatic proteinuria, persistent proteinuria occurs in people with underlying kidney disease or other medical problems It is also the signal indicator of a glomerular lesion

questions.text: On light microscopy of renal biopsy, there is visible involvement of 90% glomeruli and only a portion of that tuft. Which of the following best describes the finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diffuse segmentally Each region of a renal biopsy is assessed separately. By light microscopy, glomeruli (ideally 20) are reviewed individually for discrete lesions; <50% involvement is considered focal, and >50% is diffuse. Injury in each glomerular tuft can be segmental, involving a portion of the tuft, or global, involving most of the glomerulus.

questions.text: What is the normal annual mean decline in GFR with age after attaining a peak in the third decade?
questions.correct_answer: B. ~1 mL/min per year per 1.73 m2
questions.explanation:
Solution:

~1 mL/min per year per 1.73 m2 The normal annual mean decline in GFR with age from the peak GFR (~120 mL/min per 1.73 m2) attained during the third decade of life is ~1 mL/min per year per 1.73 m2, reaching a mean value of 70 mL/min per 1.73 m2 at age 70, with considerable inter-individual variability.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C, and D are not the correct options.

Extraedge:

Recommended Equations for Estimation of Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) Using Serum Creatinine Concentration (SCR) Age, Sex, Race, and Body Weight 1. Equation from the Modification of Diet in Renal Disease Study Estimated GFR (mL/min per 1.73 m²) = 1.86 x (S Cr ) -1.154 x (age) -0.203 Multiply by 0.742 for women Multiply by 1.21 for African ancestry (currently under review) 2. CKD-EPI Equation GFR = 141 x min(S Cr /κ, 1) α x max(S Cr /κ, 1) -1.209 × 0.993 Age Multiply by 1.018 for women Multiply by 1.159 for African ancestry (currently under review) where S Cr is serum creatinine in mg/dL, κ is 0.7 for females and 0.9 for males, α is Cr −0.329 for females and −0.411 for males, min indicates the minimum of S Cr ¸/κ or 1, and max indicates the maximum of S Cr /κ or 1.

questions.text: Fabry disease is an inherited disorder that results from the buildup of a type of fat, called globotriaosylceramide, in the body's cells. Renal biopsy reveals enlarged glomerular visceral epithelial cells packed with small clear vacuoles containing globotriaosylceramide; vacuoles may also be found in parietal and tubular epithelia. These vacuoles of electron-dense materials in parallel arrays ( zebra bodies) are easily seen on electron microscopy. Ultimately, renal biopsies reveal FSGS.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with a history of passing frothy urine. The urine routine showed 3+ proteinuria. 24-hour urine protein was found to be 4 g/24hrs. The most common cause of nephrotic range proteinuria in an adult is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetes Mellitus Causes of nephrotic syndrome- Systemic causes (25%) a. Diabetes mellitus (most common cause), SLE, Amyloidosis b. Drugs: Gold, penicillamine , probenecid , street heroin, captopril , NSAIDs c. Infections: Bacterial endocarditis, hepatitis B, shunt infections, syphilis, malaria d. Malignancy: Hodgkin’s and other lymphomas, leukemia, carcinoma of breast and GI tract e. Allergic reactions B. Glomerular disease (75%) a. Minimal change disease (90% in children and 15% in adults) b. Membranous (40% in adults) c. Focal glomerulosclerosis d. Membranoproliferative GN 2. Clinical Features - a. Patients usually present with insidious onset of generalized edema, without a decrease in urine output. b. Patients may complain of passing frothy urine due to the presence of protein. c. Nephrotic syndrome is associated with = ↑ LDL, ↑Tg, ↓ HDL d. Patients with nephrotic syndrome can develop spontaneous peripheral arterial or venous thrombosis. Specially Renal vein thrombosis due to i. Increase Fibrinogen ii. Increase Lipoproteins iii. Reduced antithrombin.

questions.text: Steroid-resistant MCD is defined as failing 16 weeks of corticosteroid treatment. Approximately 10%-20% of adults with MCD are resistant. Minimal change glomerulopathy which is steroid resistant may progress to which of the following ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FSGS The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease. Pathology:- Steroid-resistant (SR) MCD is defined as failing 16 weeks of corticosteroid treatment . Approximately 10%–20% of adults with MCD are resistant, and a repeat renal biopsy in these patients may show Diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells (Podocytes) in the glomeruli that appear virtually normal by light microscopy Immunofluorescence studies show No Ig or complement deposits The glomeruli are normal by light microscopy. The cells of the PCT are often laden with lipids and proteins, reflecting tubular reabsorption of lipoproteins, passing through diseased glomeruli (thus the historical name lipoid nephrosis for this disease) Clinically the child presents with aggressive proteinuria and there is commonly no hypertension or hematuria The proteinuria is highly selective, most of the protein having albumin Most children (90%)with minimal change disease respond rapidly to corticosteroid therapy Causes:- Idiopathic 2. Drugs - NSAID, rifampicin, IFN - alpha 3. Hodgkin's disease 4. HIV. Hepatitis B is not a cause of Minimal change glomerulopathy. Rarely minimal change GN may progress to Focal & Segmental glomerulosclerosis Treatment of minimal change GN:- Prednisone is first-line therapy, Other immunosuppressive drugs, such as cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, and mycophenolate mofetil, are saved for frequent relapses, steroid-dependent, or steroid-resistant patients. Cyclosporine can induce remission, but relapse is also common when cyclosporine is withdrawn.
